title: High-Resolution Focused-Ion Beam Scanning Electron Microscopy Reveals Differentially Organized F-actin Compartments in Cochlear Hair Cell Stereocilia
content: Inner ear auditory hair cells have projections on their apical surface known as stereocilia, which transduce sound vibrations into electrical signals. The stereocilia form a highly organized staircase, or “hair bundle”, that must be maintained over a lifetime of sound exposure. When the hair cells become damaged and die, they cannot regenerate. Decades ago, it was discovered that the stereocilium core consists of a semicrystalline array of unidirectional actin filaments [1, 2]. However, in mature mammalian hair cells, filamentous actin in the stereocilia core is extremely stable; there is only a short region at the stereocilia tips (∼500nm) where dynamic actin turnover occurs [3-5]. Therefore, ultrastructural organization of F-actin at the tips of stereocilia is likely to be different from the paracrystal actin core in the stereocilia shafts. However, these hypothesized differences in F-actin organization have never been observed experimentally.
